newsitem.title: USA: Hicks Muse to buy American Home food unit.
newsitem.headline: Hicks Muse to buy American Home food unit.

text.p: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., a private investment firm, said Friday it has signed a definitive agreement to acquire the food business of American Home Products Corp. for about $1.3 billion.
The business, which will be renamed American Home Food Products, sells packaged convenience foods primarily in the United States, with projected sales of about $1 billion in 1996.

Its products include Chef Boyardee prepared pasta products, pizza mixes, and dinner kits; PAM cooking spray, Franklin Crunch 'n Munch glazed popcorn; Polaner fruit spreads and spices; Gulden's mustard; Ranch Style Brand beans; Dennison's chili; Luck's beans; Ro*Tel tomato and chilies products; Jiffy Pop popcorn; Maypo and Wheatena hot cereals; and G. Washington broth. It also has strong foodservice and private label businesses.
American Home Products will receive about $1.2 billion in cash and will retain 20 percent of the common stock of its food unit, Hicks Muse said.

"Consistent with our proven approach of acquiring and building quality companies with exceptional management teams, this transaction provides a superb platform to execute a buy-and-build strategy in the branded food products business," said Michael J. Levitt, managing director of Hicks Muse.
Hicks Muse said Chase Securities Inc. and Bankers Trust Company will arrange financing for the transaction.
The transaction is subject to governmental approvals.

The acquisition is Hicks Muse's largest since the Dallas-based investment firm was formed in 1989. It will form a company with its food industry management affiliate, C. Dean Metropoulos & Co., to make the acquisition.

Metropoulos manages three Hicks Muse portfolio companies, The Morningstar Group Inc.; Heritage Brands, Inc., which includes Campfire marshmallows and marshmallow crisp rice bars; and Ghirardelli Chocolate Co.

Over the past six years, Hicks Muse has completed, or currently has pending, more than 55 transactions worth more than $9 billion. The firm also has offices in New York City, St. Louis, and Mexico City.
American Home Products' stock rose 37.5 cents to $59.375 on the New York Stock Exchange at mid-morning.
